Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Political Science: Explaining Post-Election Violence in Africa

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to provide an explanatory framework for understanding post-election violence (PEV) in Africa. Not only has PEV received scant theoretical and empirical treatment in the political violence and internal conflict literatures, electoral violence is consistently recurring, happening at a relatively constant rate for the past two decades even as war is on the decline. While the scant literature on electoral violence in Africa (primarily single-case studies) has shed light on the dynamics involved in particular contexts, still missing are: a systematic explanation for the occurrence of PEV across Africa, why PEV occurs in certain contexts and not in others, and a theoretically grounded general account of PEV on the continent. This project aims to provide these missing aspects.

Intellectual Merit: Theoretically, this research will provide an ideal-typical model that explains PEV in Africa to be subsequently deployed in the analysis of individual cases. Empirically, using a multi-method research design, it will provide aggregate quantitative analysis of PEV in Africa as well as in-depth case studies of three cases - two with and one without PEV. These are recent presidential elections in Ghana (2012), Nigeria (2011) and Cote d'Ivoire (2010). The case studies involve field research using semi-structured expert/elite interviews, process tracing, and discourse analysis. This research will enhance security studies by delineating the mechanisms and processes involved in PEV with policy implications for mitigating post-election violence in Africa and other newly democratizing states.

Broader Impacts: PEV has a destabilizing effect, results in loss of lives and property, and at its most extreme, leads to civil war. The gap in the literature identified above will be filled by focusing on the following questions. What accounts for the incidence of PEV? What are the mechanisms and processes involved? How can the variance in the intensity of violence seen in PEV be explained? Why does PEV degenerate into civil war? Successfully answering these questions will provide a comprehensive understanding of PEV that is crucial to coming up with effective measures for preventing and resolving PEV, with broader implications for international security, the practice and policymaking on conflict management and peacebuilding, not just in Africa but also in other newly democratizing societies. Since the U.S. as a preeminent global power is enmeshed in international security it also has national security implications as the U.S. may intervene in cases of PEV that degenerate into civil war.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to provide an explanatory framework for understanding the occurence of post-election violence (PEV)  in Africa. I do so using a a multi-method research design involving ideal-type theorizing, quantitative analysis of national elections in sub-Saharan Africa from 1990 to 2012, and qualitative case studies including field research incorporating semi-structured expert and elite interviews.

PEV has received scant  treatment in the political violence and internal conflict literatures, therefore this project makes the following contributions. Theoretically, I provide an ideal-typical model that explains PEV in Africa to be subsequently deployed in analysis of individual cases. Empirically, I engage in aggregate quantitative analysis of PEV in Africa as well as in-depth case studies of three cases – two with and one without PEV. These are recent presidential elections in Ghana (2012), Nigeria (2011) and Côte d’Ivoire (2010). This study intervenes in debates of ethnic tensions and economic variables as main causes of internal conflict. By focusing on PEV as a specific kind of internal conflict, it emphasizes the role of electoral factors as well as postcoloniality (the historical legacy of colonialism and the realities of a postcolonially organized Africa) as drivers of conflict. It also shows the importance of electoral violence prevention strategies built upon a viable peace architecture in preventing conflict.

I argue that PEV unfolds as a three-phase process—namely conditioning, exploitation and escalation—with distinct mechanisms. In the conditioning phase, disputes over resource, economic inequality, poor economic prospects, and electoral illegitimacy interact with the realities of a postcolonially organized Africa to create the conditions of possibility for violence. In the exploitation phase, when these violent-ripe conditions are accompanied by the exploitation of existing social cleavages and previously unresolved violent episodes by political entrepreneurs, as well as by violent mobilization of political party organs, the result is PEV. Progression to more intense violence and to post-election civil war occurs in the escalation phase, when the state lacks a monopoly on violence as evidenced by the existence of private militias and private armies. This escalation to violence can be interrupted/preempted at each stage by electoral violence prevention strategies.

When I apply the above framework or ideal-type to analyzing the recent presidential elections in Ghana (2012), Nigeria (2011) and Côte d’Ivoire (2010), the following are the findings and conclusions. The civil war following the 2010 presidential elections in Côte d’Ivoire is inextricably linked with decades-old previous violent episodes that have gone unresolved. Equally important is the struggle for relevance as well as control of the country among a cadre of political elite who each see themselves as significantly intertwined with the founding narrative of the country and thus the rightful heirs of carrying forward its legacy. In Nigeria  infighting and a power struggle within the ruling party based on regional alliances fueled the violent eruptions following the 2011 presidential elections. While Ghana is often perceived as the beacon of peaceful elections (which was also my assumption going into this project), its record of relatively peaceful elections compared to its African counterparts is not unblemished. Ghana's elections following the end of military rule in 1992 were not always peaceful. I argue that a series of carefully-crafted electoral violence prevention strategies by the government and civil society organs, with a heavier burden shouldered by civil society organizations has contributed to the current fragile consensus.
